I keep track of the weather, mostly temperature, pressure and storm systems, since it impacts my pain levels. Recently I've noticed our temperatures going up here in the western u.s as well.

I am in Missouri and when I noticed nights becoming warmer, over 10yrs ago now, I've noticed it has increased in how often it is happening thanks to having our own weather instruments that tell us temp, humidity, heat index, pressure, wind direction, etc, etc.
What bothered me last year, is we started having nights that would increase by a whole 10 degrees after the sun set.
This week, the rises haven't been as drastic, but the heat index certainly has been! On Monday (June 13th 2022), the heat index was 158!!
Actual temp was 103, and the "feels like", was 125!
I don't recall having those temps growing up (and I haven't moved out of state).

Also, is there a link between areas that have had a growth in housing/business developement, and shrinking water table levels?

Last year, we had our pipe to the pump lowered to get to the water because it had lowered, and we're about a 10-15min drive from a town with a big growth in housing.
More housing, more water from below gets pumped up. And I've been learning how that affects nearby areas in their water levels too.
We need to stop wasting water and have less homes, not more homes.
There's vacation homes that are taking up space where people could live. Big mansions that aren't needed, only wanted for greed or looks, take up space and waste more materials than smaller homes.

Think of this: less is more (but yea not when it comes to money. If you've been homeless, you know what I mean).

It's a shame that in a video about asymmetric warming you didn't mention urban heat islands! We're literally painting the earth with heat-absorbing asphalt which traps huge amounts of heat in the daytime and releases that heat throughout the night. It's such a big issue that it has observable effects on the weather and climate in the region, with between ~50% to ~120% increases in precipitation downwind of large cities, and plant growing seasons noticeably longer within several miles of a large city. There are numerous studies linking UHI to climate change, with findings indicating moderate to significant impact on the earth's climate.

I remember this being a problem when I worked at a plant nursery a few years back. People kept coming in and calling us to find out why their tomato plants weren't producing even though it should have been the peak season. And the reason why is because it wasn't getting below 80 degrees Fahrenheit at night, which even though tomatoes are usually thought of as a heat loving plant, they need cooler nights in order to bloom.

My biggest issue with most global warming arguments is that they blame carbon. The largest source of carbon released to our atmosphere is the ocean. The warmer it gets, the more CO2 is released. If excess carbon was the cause of global warming, then the earth would keep getting warmer and warmer until everything died. Methane though, that makes more sense. However, if you look at global temperatures over millions of years and not just thousands, you’ll see that the earth has gone through many of these cycles long before humans came along. Using shorter times scales that don’t show the big picture is deceitful. We definitely need to clean our act up. I agree with that. I just feel like we aren’t getting the full truth.

Grade 8 science fair project. We took three tubes and exposed them to sun light for an hour, recording temperatures every ten minutes. We then put them in the shade for an hour and recorded temperatures. We filled one with CO2, one with methane, and one with regular air. The amazing result was that not only did the CO2 and Methane tubes heat up more, they kept their high temperatures for much longer than the regular air filled tube.

Overall, a good compilation of climate change information. The most important omission in the discussion is how the world needs to adapt to these changing conditions beyond "warming and wetting conditions at a location are bad". In the natural world, both vegetation and animals will migrate in the directions towards the poles with some endangered species lacking places to migrate to. Transplanting endangered species will be required to prevent their extinction. In agricultural areas, we need to help poor farmers adapt the crops they grow or change the crops they grow so their livelihood is not reduced.

Then when I was about 12 it started to stop snowing 3-4 times a winter and when it did the snow began to melt off in 4 days.

The ten warmest years on record is a meaningless statement. First, our records date back only into the 1700s and we have only reached a point where we have actual world wide coverage in the 20th century. Also, we know for a fact that the Medieval warming period was several degrees warmer than the average temperature today. Third, several of those record temperature readings are a fraction of a degree higher than the last record and fell within the margin of error, meaning that they really weren't an increase in temperature - it just sounds more scary if you tell half the story.
Also, the issue of whether climate change is man made or not is not settled. Reference back to the afore mentioned Medieval warming period with no carbon emissions to blame. At least one study (supported by data) demonstrated that the relationship between warming and CO2 levels is the inverse of what science is proposing: the climate got warmer and then the CO2 levels rose in response throughout history. There are a fair number of climatologists who correctly attribute warming and cooling mainly to solar activity. That position doesn't get you press time or research dollars like a good scary theory that we're all going to die, unfortunately, so you don't hear that side on the "If it bleeds, it leads" news programs. An alternative explanation to the greenhouse effect theories is that the temperature really isn't rising in any significant way, but that the places we take the temperature have changed from rural settings with the cooling effects of trees and plants to the heat retaining concrete canyons of urban and suburban civilization.

Those pics with people sleeping in front of an open fridge: Eons ago, I read a study where they tested if leaving the refrigerator door open cooled the room. It did not. It actually warmed the room because the appliance had to work harder to maintain temperature and that created more heat.

It may feel good in the short term but in the long term, doing that just makes it worse. I know those were just stock images to make a point, but there's idiots out there who think it's a good thing to do to cool off. And duct tape can't fix that kind of stupid. I've tried.
